column1: In theory
column2: this is an excellent Cher compilation. The cover is lovely (and the first from Universal's 'Gold' series to deviate from their uniform aesthetic) and the tracklisting is a satisfactory overview of Cher's career. It certainly tops the domestic release of 'The Very Best of Cher' which was a skin-and-bones effort intended to offer the essential Cher songs and little else. Australia
column3: Canada and parts of Europe
column4: however
column5: ended up with a far more interesting 2CD package. With a CD-busting length of 42 tracks
column6: this deluxe release of 'The Very Best of Cher' leaves 'Gold' for dead. Although the two vary slightly on the earlier inclusions (you won't find Cher's brash reading of 'Alfie' on 'The Very Best of Cher'
column7: nor the iconic 'You Better Sit Down Kids' and 'Living In A House Divided) every song on 'Gold' appears on 'The Very Best of Cher' along with a healthy smattering of oft-forgotten cuts. Neither compilation addresses Cher's Warner albums from the mid-seventies
column8: a shame considering 'Stars' and 'I'd Rather Believe In You' contain some of her best ever recordings
column9: but at least 'The Very Best of Cher' makes more of an attempt to bridge the gap. 'Rudy' from 1982's 'I Paralyze' is a welcome inclusion
column10: as is her otherwise unavailable on a Cher album disco cut 'Bad Love'. The Meat Loaf duet 'Dead Ringer For Love'
column11: a staple of Cher's hilarious/fabulous eighties schlock rock period
column12: is also included
column13: as is a cut from Cher's 1994 'not.com.mercial' CD which was sold exclusively through her website a few years back. There are also five songs from Cher's latest studio release 'Living Proof' which might seem slightly excessive
column14: but the songs are frighteningly fun so the decision is justified.  Although the un-chronological sequencing on 'The Very Best of Cher' is rather frustrating - in that respect
column15: 'Gold' is a more effective compilation - on content alone there is no contest. For the casual fan
column16: the 2CD 'The Very Best of Cher' will be the only Cher album they ever need to own. For hardcores
column17: it remains the most satisfying compilation and even offers a couple of rarities that make it a worthy purchase. Had Universal included a couple of unavailable tracks from Cher's mid-seventies period it would have scored extra brownie points
column18: but as it stands 'Gold' is a fairly redundant release for the Cher connossieur and casual fans alike. The 2CD import version of 'The Very Best of Cher' is available here at Amazon. It may be twice the price but it is a far better investment

column1: Simultaneously examining the first
column2: second
column3: and third waves of American feminism in her unprecedented volume
column4: Sara M. Evans unwittingly squanders the tremendous potential from her initially good intentions.   Falling into the same 'post-feminist' trap readers are ironically warned against throughout the text
column5: this book cannot unify second and third wavers. I certainly appreciate and have benefited from the work accomplished during this time period and am personally/professionally friends with individuals
column6: but cannot see how a book ignoring my own generation's political activism is supposed to unify the two generations at large  Sharply contrasting with the glowing treatment given to herself and other second wavers
column7: Evans only introduces the third wave as "recent participants in a world transformed by their mother's generation" (p. 213). In addition to implying that myself and others are really only interloping guests at 'somebody' else's social justice movement
column8: this remark overlooks the critical perspectives we bring precisely as a consequence of growing up without legal segregation
column9: with Title IX
column10: Special Education
column11: and many other programs which were only a dream for her generation.   While giving the 'riot grrrl' movement only one paragraph
column12: she is oddly eager to devote much more book space to the faux feminists who made their public names attacking previous feminist theory (p. 221). Agreeing that it made for great mass media sensationalism
column13: I do not accept this latter category as representative of my generation of feminist theorists
column14: and am disappointed by Evans's stereotypes.   After ironically establishing how bias keeps women from being aware of their past (p. 38) she then specifically minimizes a feminism (which unlike the drivel by Roiphe
column15: Summers
column16: and Hoff) represented a major public resurgence of progressive ideas. Riot Grrrl theory argued that all forms of oppression are connected although patriarchy under girds this society. Just because something is different from her own generation does not excuse Evans from taking it seriously during the research process.      Other truly intergenerational feminist authors previously have argued the movement needs to make genuine efforts either to fully become or remain multigenerational
column17: but Evans is blissfully oblivious to this necessity. In it's current state the book has no academic or personal redeeming quality and substantial revisions are needed to accord equal respect to all feminist generations.

column1: A daring young atomic scientist teams up with three high school seniors to attempt the first-ever rocket trip to the moon -- that's the premise of Heinlein's Rocket Ship Galileo.  Readers who aren't immediately turned off by the story's wild improbabilities and dated subject matter may find this book an entertaining adventure.  To begin with
column2: Heinlein's story is well paced and solidly constructed for once
column3: a pleasant change from the episodic hodgepodges he created in his later years.  He skillfully introduces elements of conflict at an early stage of the story
column4: (as sinister forces seem to be trying to prevent the voyage from taking place) and he even manages to build some suspense
column5: an effect Heinlein is not usually noted for.  His descriptions of the mechanics of the moon rocket and its voyage are both convincing and interesting
column6: despite being badly dated.  One real letdown is the characters
column7: who are curiously undeveloped
column8: even for science fiction.  The three boys themselves are virtually interchangeable
column9: and Doctor Cargraves isn't much more distinctive.  If some attempt had been made to give these young men their own individual personalities
column10: the readers might find them easier to identify with.  As it is
column11: it's hard to really care about these characters
column12: even when something horrible happens to them.  The really big problem
column13: though
column14: is that this book really hasn't aged very well. For example
column15: Heinlein tries to show us how a moon rocket was outfitted and launched privately
column16: by one scientist and his youthful helpers
column17: working on a shoestring budget
column18: after a few months of labor; when after all
column19: any schoolchild knows that it took NASA and the U.S. government billions of dollars
column20: working with hundreds of the finest minds on the planet for nearly a decade
column21: to accomplish the real thing.  Once our heroes reach the moon
column22: the story gets even more improbable
column23: as they find that the moon is already inhabited.  Naturally
column24: Heinlein wrote this novel for younger readers
column25: and it was published at a time when space travel seemed utterly impossible.  As such
column26: it was written for the tastes of the times
column27: and times have changed dramatically.  For instance
column28: the only women in this book are the boys' mothers
column29: who have very little to say about anything important.  The villains are cartoonish stereotypes
column30: who are summarily dispatched without any show of remorse.  Although the book is reasonably well-written overall
column31: and older readers may take some nostalgic pleasure in its simplicity and naivet
column32: today's young readers may want something more wildly speculative than a moon landing.  On average
column33: if you're old enough to remember Sputnik
column34: you can be forgiven for loving this book; but if Neil Armstrong is just another boring guy you heard about in school
column35: you probably won't be too impressed by Rocket Ship Galileo

column1: Hang on a minute.  I don't understand what's going on here...The book is called 'Halliwell's Film
column2: Video And Dvd Guide 2005 by John Walker' according to the front cover.  So who wrote it?  Leslie Halliwell or John Walker?  Leslie Halliwell was a superlative film critic/historian
column3: but he died in 1989.  It shouldn't be allowed for a book to be called 'Halliwell's...' unless it's written by him alone. The fact is that Halliwell is NOT a brand name.  It's the name of an author who died in 1989.  He wrote the entire books himself - He wasn't just the curator of a collection - he was an author in his own right.  To start adding further reviews by John Walker means it is no longer Halliwell's guide. Simple as that...  Why isn't there a Walker's Film
column4: Video And Dvd Guide 2005 by John Walker? Presumably because it wouldn't sell as many copies.  If you want the genuine Halliwell article then please search out ebay for copies from the 80s.    What next?  The complete Works of Shakespeare by John Walker?

column1: I read this book and several others on the subject to help myself recover from a painful life-long relationship with an untreated
column2: undiagnosed ADDer. My goal was to understand
column3: and have compassion for those with ADD.  This book seems to be aimed at making those who have to live with ADD or ADHD feel good. In an attempt to make the ADDer feel better
column4: he takes the approach that ADD is an outdated human survival mechanism that causes problems in our more organized society
column5: therefore
column6: it is not a "defect" or something that needs to be treated with medication.   The tendency to pile on fat is also such a mechanism
column7: but that is no reason to consider it a "gift" or not seek ways to overcome it. The reality is that such things can pose very real health risks and the danger is that such opinions can assist those in denial to ignore the consequences of ADD/ADHD behavior on the family's health
column8: happiness
column9: and survival.  He also blames a lot of the increase in ADD on a society that watches TV
column10: and an education system that stifles creativity. Many people try to link ADD with creativity as though one relies on the other. However
column11: there are a lot of us that have grown up in the same environment as those with ADHD
column12: but we manage to remember to pay the bills
column13: we can maintain a job
column14: and we manage to maintain healthy human relationships. And there are many artists
column15: musicians and creative individuals who do not have ADD
column16: and are no less successful for it.  If you are the parent of an ADD/ADHD child
column17: there are some good tips for parenting. But if you are a spouse or child recovering from a disastrous relationship with someone with undiagnosed or untreated ADD
column18: or if you are currently in a relationship with an adult with untreated ADD this book won't help you a bit.  There is no doubt that our society has been bad at helping those with ADD and our attitudes toward the behavior of ADD have caused self-esteem problems. However
column19: the same is true of the overweight issue.  The bottom line is that ADD and ADHD has caused an untold amount of unhappiness for the person with ADD and the family. The behaviors of risk taking
column20: the communication problems that manifest in relationship problems
column21: and the impulsiveness and lack of self control that can lead to emotional or physical abuse are far too serious to be ignored. The exercises in the book are fine
column22: but for anyone facing serious issues because of ADD behavior
column23: think about medication to get the worst of the behavior under control. If medication can help treat it
column24: I say
column25: go for it. Then we can all sit in a circle and sing Kumbayah and rejoice in our "differentness"

column1: Woods has produced a silly anti-history of the U.S. in the hopes of generating a little revenue by finding a spot on the lunatic right-wing fringe bookshelf. Among things you will learn: The Whites treated Indians just fine and talks of exploitation are overblown. Blacks in the South were a contented lot
column2: and the whole system was ruined by racists like Abraham Lincoln and the later Radical Republicans. Woodrow Wilson led the U.S. into World War One despite America's resistance to doing so. No mention of Teddy Roosevelt and the " Preparedness " movement. Also no mention that it was Congress that overwhelmingly approved the war declaration. And wouldn't you know it? In post World War II

column4: and there was no need for federal intrusion

column6: or even a Civil Rights or Voting act.  Woods even briefly makes a foray into sports to show how segregation was crumbling

How did Nicole Kidman have a dream about an orgy the same night as the real one? How did the mask end up in the bed? Was there really foul play involved in death of the junkie prostitute and the quick exit of the piano player? What the hell was the point of this movie?   P.S. London only looks like New York City if you don't live in New York City

column1: Having loved both the Arthur Waley and Edward Seidensticker versions of The Tale of Genji as well as the bits and pieces of Murasaki Shikibu's classical Japanese I had hammered through as a graduate student in East Asian studies
column2: I was thrilled to hear that someone had done a "stunning" new translation of this work I and so many other Genji fans regard as one of the greatest "novels" ever written. Fortunately
column3: a friend of mine
column4: who is also a Genji fan
column5: had the foresight to forward me some random passages of the Tyler version before I actually shelled out any money. In comparing these quotes to the Waley and Seidensticker versions I was much surprised to find that the Tyler translation comes up short in almost every regard
column6: and that even Seidensticker's version
column7: engaging as it is
column8: is somewhat disappointing. Compare their respective translations of this short passage from a scene in Chapter Five ("Murasaki")
column9: where Genji is visiting a Buddhist monastery in the mountains:  Waley's version:  Genji felt very disconsolate. It had begun to rain; a cold wind blew across the hill
column10: carrying with it the sound of a waterfall--audible till then as a gentle intermittent plashing
column11: but now a mighty roar; and with it
column12: somnolently rising and falling
column13: mingled the monotonous chanting of the scriptures. Even the most unimpressionable nature would have been plunged into melancholy by such surroundings. How much the more so Prince Genji
column14: as he lay sleepless on his bed
column15: continually planning and counter-planning.   Seidensticker's version: Genji was not feeling well. A shower passed on a chilly mountain wind
column16: and the sound of the waterfall was higher. Intermittently came a rather sleepy voice
column17: solemn and somehow ominous
column18: reading a sacred text. The most insensitive of men would have been aroused by the scene. Genji was unable to sleep.  Tyler's version:  Genji felt quite unwell
column19: and besides
column20: it was now raining a little
column21: a cold mountain wind had set in to blow
column22: and the pool beneath the waterfall had risen until the roar was louder than before. The eerie swelling and dying of somnolent voices chanting the scriptures could hardly fail in such a setting to move the most casual visitor. No wonder Genji
column23: who had so much to ponder
column24: could not sleep.  There is no doubt Waley embellished the text
column25: but it was clearly in the interest of conveying a sense of the exquisite poetry of Murasaki's prose. His elevated diction lends just that touch of "class" we would expect to find in an author writing for an aristocratic audience for whom style was everything. Moreover
column26: the sumptuous musicality of his phrasing continually underscores the melancholy atmosphere even as it seems to echo the sound of the waterfall and the chanting. Seidensticker's version has the virtue of concision
column27: but his choice of words is often questionable: "reading
column28: for example, suggests that Buddhist monks read the sutras in private meditation rather than chanted them as a group prayer. His sacred texts
column29: on the other hand, implies that Genji wasn't very familiar with Buddhism, which could hardly be further from the truth. It was as central to his life and worldview as Catholicism was to the Italian princes of the Middle Ages, as Waley's scriptures" implies. The phrase "aroused by the scene" is even more ill-chosen
column30: for it suggests that Genji found visits to mountain temples erotically stimulating
column31: when in fact they tended to have the opposite effect
column32: for they reminded him of the vanity of his secular pursuits
column33: which were
column34: by and large
column35: erotic.   Tyler's version follows Waley's interpretation at this point and thus avoids these particular problems
column36: but he has others that are even worse. His "a cold mountain wind had set in to blow
column37: for example, is dreadfully clumsy and somewhat confusing, as is his the pool beneath the waterfall had risen until the roar was louder than before". The latter illogically suggests that it was the increased height of the pool below the waterfall that made the roar louder rather than the increase in the volume of water flowing over the falls due to the rain that had passed. A good many phrases in the other passages I sampled from the Tyler volume had similar kinds of problems
column38: which makes me wonder if Tyler's editors ever bothered to read the work they insist is so "stunning."  If any version deserves that praise it is Waley's
column39: which may be difficult to find
column40: but it is well worth the effort

column1: After many years
column2: I decided to finally give Kathy Reichs' Temperance Brennan series a go.  So
column3: where better to start than her debut novel 'Deja Dead' which introduces Reichs' heroine.  Temperance Brennan is an American forensic anthropologist working in Montreal for what I'm guessing is the French-Canadian equivalent of a Medical Examiner's office.  Of course our heroine is head strong
column4: independent
column5: and unlucky in love (aren't they all?).  Well
column6: some murders start turning up and
column7: amazingly enough
column8: our intrepid anthropologist is the only person that links the crimes together.  Do the police believe her?  No
column9: so she must investigate the crimes on her own.  And by doing so
column10: the murderer then turns his attention to Brennan and her family and friends (don't all killers eventually do that?).  First off
column11: the book is bloated.  The book (at least the paperback version) clocks in at about 530 pages.  Reichs' writes too much about menial tasks that her character
column12: Brennan
column13: does during her usual day.  Does anyone really want to hear repeatedly about what a character had for dinner or what paperwork she does at work?  I know I don't want to read it.  Now I'm a person who enjoys a nice
column14: long book but 'Deja Dead' (where did she get that title anyway?) is about two hundred pages too long.  And it is a very slow read.    Secondly
column15: her main character
column16: Brennan
column17: just isn't likeable.  In fact
column18: I found her quite annoying.  The policemen in the novel are portrayed as incompetent
column19: arrogant jerks who are too worried about being right than they are about doing the right thing.  When in fact I think that they just didn't want to deal with this overly nosy anthropologist who is obviously stepping on toes and irritating people who are just trying to do their jobs.  Reichs' tries to portray Brennan as a lone crusader fighting against all these odds to get to the criminal.  When in fact she is an irritating anthropologist who has no business investigating a murder.  She is
column20: basically
column21: a laboratory-based employee who should not be in the field.  So I don't blame the cops in the book that don't like her.  She's butting her nose in where it doesn't belong and
column22: in a part I actually liked
column23: she ends up bringing irreparable damage to her family and friends.  I thought it a just outcome.  Also
column24: after about the twentieth time of Brennan looking at some cop's rear end and saying "I like the way his butt looks...Oh
column25: stop!  You need to get laid." I wanted to scream.  Dr. Brennan
column26: at least in this debut novel
column27: is extremely irritating.  Thirdly
column28: I have read the basic plot of this book in a hundred other novels.  The suprise "switcheroo" ending is not suprising but more annoying...  It is just a cheap way to trick the reader.  And if I have to read about one more main character who ends up becoming the target of the "killer"
column29: I will scream.  Its pathetic.  How many times does it need to be written?  Its ridiculous.  Now
column30: 'Deja Dead' is the first of Reichs' books that I've read.  I've heard that the following books in the Brennan series are better and I certainly hope this is the case.  I really didn't like the book:  not the characters
column31: the plot

column1: Francis Bacon said that some books are meant to be chewed
column2: some swallowed
column3: and some digested.  This book is meant to be spit out.    I recently returned to the college classroom as a student of Human Anatomy and of Nutrition (preparing for entrance into a nursing program).  For those classes I read
column4: respectively
column5: Marieb's "Human Anatomy and Physiology" and Whitney's "Understanding Nutrition."  The contrast between these two widely-used textbooks could not be greater.  The one is clearly written
column6: lucidly organized
column7: and filled with revealing graphics; the other is horribly opaque
column8: repetitive and senseless in organization
column9: and replete with distracting charts and photos.  Comparisons are odious
column10: so I will just amplify my main points and have done.  This book reads as though written by someone who is more anxious to prove the scientific merit of her field or her own expertise in the latest research than by someone interested in helping the reader understand major concepts for further study.  Virtually every paragraph has the main point--if there is one--obscured somewhere in the fourth sentence
column11: with irrelevant detail draped around it
column12: so that the reader is forced to do the work the writer should have done.  You can learn about nutrition by reading this book in spite of the style
column13: not because of it.  The last three or four chapters on nutrition in the life cycle and diet and health repeat what was presented in various places in earlier chapters on digestion and on nutrients.  After reading a popular book on nutrition by a professor at Cambridge(Brown's "Energy of Life") that was clear
column14: concise
column15: and not condescending
column16: I inferred that Whitney has succumbed to the disease afflicting many textbook writers:  the structure and content are dictated by the editors' anxiety to keep up with the competition rather than by the author's own insight.  On virtually every page
column17: there is a photo
column18: chart
column19: or graphic that distracts or insults the reader's efforts to learn about nutrition.  A stray "factoid" about calories crams the margin or a photo of a vegetable pulls the eye away from the discussion.  Evidently the editors feel the subject itself is not interesting enough to keep my attention.  They're right
column20: when it's presented in such a haphazard and condescending way.  If this book were not used regularly around the nation as a textbook in many courses
column21: it would long ago have disappeared from the market
column22: since no ordinary intelligent person would voluntarily wade through its turgid
column23: repetitive
column24: and insulting bulk.  I'm outraged that this book is so expensive and so lousy.  I sold my copy on Amazon the instant the course was over (whereas I cherish my copy of Marieb's book and can't wait to read it again).  It's a shame
column25: because now I must look for another book on nutrition
column26: one that I can read and gain insight from with pleasure on an important subject

column1: I expected this book to be fun take on the Hollywood nanny experience where the reader can peek at the "other side" and perhaps try to guess who might be the real people behind the pseudonyms.  Nope.  Susanne Hansen is a cad who betrays her former employers (and her nanny friends' employers) by exposing their private family dynamics for entertainment and ridicule.  It would have been much
column2: MUCH better had she changed names and focused more on the celebrity lifestyle gossipy end of it than in her own boring self-examinations and snotty judgements.  In every page she obsesses over wealth and then condemns the very people whose assets she admires.  She seems to think that shallow and neglectful parenting is something only to be found in the nanny-hiring set.  There was no joy in reading this book once I realized that while she may have changed the children's names
column3: the names of the parents were quite real.  It puts the lie to how much she felt for her charges that she would so humiliate their parents in pursuit of the almighty dollar

column1: As a preschool teacher who tries to include all kinds of traditions in my classroom
column2: I'm always on the lookout for a new fun book.  The kids do love I Know and Old Lady Who Swallowed a Fly.  That book is so preposterous - who could REALLY swallow a horse?  However
column3: this book takes the tradition of eating too much at Thanksgiving way overboard
column4: with the woman who eats a family sized meal on her own
column5: and ends up as a blimp sized balloon in the holiday parade.  The illustrations show her bumpy fat body getting bigger and bigger.  Children are already taught too young that they will get fat if they overeat.  Childhood eating disorders are on the rise. One study showed that 40% of 4th graders are on diets.  Children point out fat people to their parents in public
column6: and parents never know what to say - it's hard to teach size-acceptance and tolerance in general to a child in the first place
column7: but to add these pictures and negative stereotypes of fat people to a child's imaginative repertoire is not necessarily a good idea. 1 star for this book is 1 too many

The tone of this book also stunned me - it is apparent that the author thinks of these fish as a source of income rather than as pets. Mention is made of fish that are not "exciting or saleable

and how sub-standard hatchlings should be culled or disposed of. I was quite offended by this - even the most dully-colored betta could find a happy home somewhere! The only reason I'm giving this book one star at all is because there are a lot of beautiful photos inside. It looks more like a picture book than anything else, actually. Very disappointing

column1: I found this book to be very short on any kind of meat or details. I'm very tempted to ask for my money back. There is no insight here - the book could have been compiled from a series of press releases. I think the standard of the book is typified by the 'bibliography' which seems to list every single article the author has ever written
column2: including in magazines like Computer Shopper a  decade ago. How that is supposed to be any help to anybody I cannot see. Do yourself a favor and skip this one

column1: As with any anthology
column2: the appeal and the quality of the essays here varies
column3: but what prompted me to write a review is the extraordinary tone of smug superiority that wafts off of all too many of those found here. The most egregious example of that smugness is to be found in a vicious little piece by Sally Bellerose in which she regales the reader with her saintly forebearance as she describes the horrors bestowed upon her delicate consciousness when she deigns to honor her reactionary parents with her presence at their dinner table. And could you have a book of this kind without including that Queen of Noble Suffering
column4: Maya Angelou? She's represented here with a snippet from her often anthologized book "Wouldn't Take Nothin' For My Journey Now." There's also the pro forma male bashing in many of the essays ("Now I cook as a woman
column5: free of that feeling of enslavement with which a male culture has imbued the process of preparing food.") There's also the stereotyping that often goes along with this kind of generic thinking; eg. "Everyone knows that TV dinners are mainly the province of heterosexual males and the career woman who lives alone. Gay men often enjoy cooking and are generally as good at it as the most creative woman." The editor is a professor in the women's studies program at U. Mass
column6: Amherst. I doubt there's much room for discussion in her classes
column7: unless that discussion serves her dogma. It's not the politics I disliked so much as it is the unquestioned assumptions and the tone of sanctimony that cling to these memory scraps.  If you're already in the choir
column8: this book will be happy to preach at you
column9: but if you have yet to sign off on every blessed stereotype of oppression
column10: you may find it annoying in some places
column11: offensive in others

column1: Absolutely no power whatsoever. If you have true back or shoulder pain you are better off with a hand massage or standing under the shower. No power at all in this machine.
I had such high hopes for this book
column2: based on its description.  And in spite of the author's sometimes hard-to-follow writing style - she does love to start in one place and wander quite far from the original subject before finally winding her way back - for the first few chapters I managed to hold on to those hopes.    But in the end
column3: I would have to classify this book as 80 percent disappointment.  Charlotte is set up to be a very sympathetic character: Married to a man she loves
column4: but trapped in the family home surrounded by a seemingly endless supply of in-laws (also all residents of the family home)
column5: none of whom have ever made much of an effort to make her feel a part of the family.  Charlotte has been unable to bear a child to term in all the years of the marriage
column6: and her 10 months in a sickbed seem to have put the final distance between her and her husband
column7: Hays.  Finally
column8: after an inexplicable recovery (the author never bothers to give any hint of why Charlotte is suddenly well after all this time)
column9: Charlotte is off to surprise her husband at the wake for one of his recently deceased uncles.  But what she encounters is Hays and a mystery woman
column10: just about to share a kiss.   Calling in a favor from the local baker and his wife
column11: Charlotte finds herself at the hotel of the title
column12: facing a chilly reception from Mrs. Petty - the former cook in Charlotte's in-law's house - who had been the one to first tell Charlotte about the hotel. (Though not about the details of what goes on there.)  To this point
column13: the book was enjoyable.  But once Charlotte lands in the hotel
column14: the book heads into a decline from which it never recovers.    The efforts of the hotel's owner
column15: his staff and Charlotte's Aunt Lily - a surprise "regular" at the hotel - to get Charlotte out of the hotel were understandable
column16: if a little tedious.  Arthur's attachment to Charlotte is pretty sudden
column17: and regardless of how she feels about Hays' cheating on her
column18: it seems a little odd that she would embark on an affair with Arthur quite so easily.  And unless the author is planning a sequel
column19: there were things in this book that just didn't seem to have a reason for being.  Charlotte's introduction to the hotel owner's wife and her servant
column20: for example.  An interesting enough scene
column21: but to what purpose?    The artist who created all the paintings in the hotel - introduced
column22: then killed off.   Mrs. Petty and her children - suddenly packed off to another situation
column23: for the good of the children.  Sure
column24: we learn who the father of one of the children is
column25: but again - why?  Charlotte's parents
column26: who have been conspicuously absent from Charlotte's thoughts for a good portion of the book - there's no purpose to their appearance at the end
column27: nor really to Charlotte's search for them.  The ending
column28: as mentioned by another reviewer
column29: is the worst part of the book.  Why does Charlotte do what she does when she leaves the hotel?  Is it guilt
column30: a desire for reconciliation?    Charlotte frustrates me...I don't know what she wants
column31: and most of the time she doesn't seem to know
column32: either.  In the end
column33: I didn't care much about this book
column34: except to wonder about the several chapters that seemed to have been lopped off the end.  Maybe they would have wrapped things up in a better fashion.  I won't read this book again
column35: and I certainly can't recommend it to others.

column1: For a political junkie
column2: this one is a nice start
column3: as it really does provide some of the 'behind the scenes' commentary and detail others lack.  However
column4: having said that
column5: I was really disappointed with how little detail the book did provide on the campaigns.  Yes
column6: it's perfectly obvious the Newsweek staff got a lot closer to the Kerry campaign than they did to the Bush campaign.  And yes
column7: that means they treat the Kerry side of the story with a lot more sympathy than they do the Bush side.  It surprised me how much of the inside Kerry story never got out during the campaign (I watched the election campaign obsessively
column8: I admit it).  It also surprised me that one of the key Kerry gaffes (I would have authorized Bush to go to war even knowing about the lack of WMDs) nearly was killed by the press on the Kerry campaign and the book spends two pages on the discussion of whether or not to report it.  It would certainly seem to
column9: at a bare minimum
column10: indicate that the press was a lot more willing to give Kerry the benefit of the doubt than Bush
column11: and subsequent revelations only reinforce that thought.   Having said that
column12: I have to say that the Bush campaign may have did themselves more harm than good in keeping the press at arms length
column13: as it may have led to less favorable coverage simply because they couldn't get access for an inside scoop.  The fear that that scoop would be invariably negative seems the reason for that decision
column14: but it may not have been the best one
column15: as there were Bush-favoring press and columnists out there
column16: though few and far between.  What surprised me the most was not what was in the book
column17: but what was left out of it.  Not a word on Republican reactions during the Democratic Convention.  Very little on the foreign policy disasters that Bush was having (Abu Gharib
column18: the Spanish pulling out of Iraq after March 11th
column19: etc).  Nothing on the Democratic 527s and if they coordinated their message with the Democrats
column20: as it is implied quite strongly throughout the book.  Very little on the Swift Boat Veterans for Truth
column21: only covering them in August
column22: when junkies like me were at least somewhat aware of them back in April.  No discussion of the book the SBVT wrote
column23: or of any of their charges
column24: just a quick dismissal of them as unfounded and baseless
column25: which strikes me as very foolish
column26: as I think they were one of the key elements in Kerry's loss.  Almost nothing on the Bush National Guard memos
column27: I was very interested to know what both campaigns thought of them and they could hardly have been brought up and forgotten so quickly.  Very little analysis of the debates and on the mysterious thing under Bush's jacket in the first debate.  I think it was later found to be a bullet-proof vest.  Michael Moore and his watch for dirty tricks on election day movement
column28: and movie
column29: and support of the Democrats
column30: similarly ignored.  The entire Bruce Springsteen campaign to bring out younger voters
column31: never touched.  And aside from a very few brief mentions
column32: nothing at all on the economy
column33: and how that might have affected the campaigns.  In short
column34: some nice behind-the-scenes tidbits
column35: but sorely lacking in a lot of issues and failing utterly in terms of analysis

column1: I agree with some of the less favorable reviews.  Many of the people in the book came from big named schools and were very well off financially before thinking about a life change.  Some of the stories left you wondering what happened.  And so many of the stories were just not long enough to really provide useful insight into anyone's life.  It was like Po had a stopwatch set for 30 minutes and told each person he interviewed to tell them a little about themselves and their career path.      I'm a recent graduate from a non ivy league school.  After majoring in Business
column2: I've been struggling to just simply get experience in the areas of business I like (or any area at this point).  I thought this book would provide stories to which I could relate
column3: but for the most part there were none.  I was hoping for some inspirational stories on what steps I could take to find the right job that would lead to the right opportunities that would make me happy and financially secure.  Instead
column4: many of the people would make tons of money and then simplify their lives by baking cakes or opening a catfish farm which is fine when you're already financially secure.  That also was annoying.  It always seemed like people in the book had to make less money to be happier.  I understand that makes sense in some cases
column5: but the book made it seem like it was the only way.  Even Po kept talking about how he could have made 300 grand a year
column6: but decided against it.  Isn't it possible your calling could lead you to more money?  I am not selfish
column7: money is not everything to me
column8: but I do understand that you do in fact need it.      I gave this book 2 stars
column9: because there was one quote that I did like and made sense to me.  "The true search is what you believe in."  As opposed to only looking at what you're good at.  I think the book needed much more inspirational insight like this.  There were a few other parts of the book that provoked some deep thought
column10: but unfortunately it was more miss then hit.  I wish I could give it 2 1/2 stars
column11: because that would better demonstrate just how down the middle
column12: okay
column13: and simply average the book was.  Don't buy this book expecting it to be an eye opener.      Lets face it
column14: the question "What should I do with my life?" can never be truely anwsered.  It's like pondering about god or the universe.  I just wanted it to make me think "oh wow
column15: that's an interesting way to think about it or approach that question."  Instead
column16: I was almost always left thinking "Um okay
column17: so did I miss something there?"

column1: While visiting some family in Utah a few years ago we decided to rent a few movies to pass the unforgivably hot mid-summer weather.  We ended up renting "Analyze That" and boy
column2: what a mistake that was!  We were expecting at least a mildly funny sequel to 1999's "Analyze This."  The potential was there
column3: it's not as if writers (of course it's never a good sign to see numerous writers) Peter Tolan
column4: Peter Steinfeld
column5: and Harold Ramis didn't have decent material to work with; Robert DeNiro
column6: Billy Crystal
column7: Lisa Kudrow
column8: and a funny and entertaining plotline regarding mobsters and therapy.  However
column9: this being Hollywood and all
column10: another sequel was botched.  It's because of movies like these that sequels have such a bad reputation.    Despite a few genuine laughs in the first twenty minutes or so regarding DeNiro and some "fish out of water" situations
column11: the movie seemed to go downhill soon after.  The jokes became few and between as the film laboriously plowed its way through an over-the-top heist setup and execution that felt about as inspired as "Crossroads."  Now either they ran out of jokes
column12: they didn't have enough time to invest in an actual story
column13: or the material itself has been played out in so many different ways already ("The Sopranos"
column14: "The Whole 9 Yards"
column15: "Mickey Blue Eyes"
column16: etc. etc.)
column17: that there was simply nothing left to write about

column1: The book starts by bringing you straight into the feeling of despair and alienation Elaine and her husband Paul are experiencing in their suburban life. You feel a vague sympathy for them and wonder
column2: "what must be going on in their lives to make them feel so trapped?"  This question is never really answered. The book spends time expressing this depressing state of being in various satirical situations
column3: but never gets beyond the expression of that feeling
column4: which we get from the first page of the book. She offers no insight on why the characters came to feel the way they do
column5: or what they can do to get out of it. As a character portrait all that is fashioned for the protagonist Elaine is the feeling of helplessness; no other aspects of her psyche or personality are defined. We learn nothing about her thoughts
column6: views on the world
column7: personality
column8: or patterns of thinking that may give us a hint as to why she got that way. The same can be said for Paul.   Their environment gives us few clues as well. They live the typical life of a suburban family. They have good kids
column9: good money
column10: and good friends. Since we have seen this story portrayed in many better books and movies before
column11: we can guess what the problems of their environment are. They feel they have to put up a front of stability and happiness for the people they are around
column12: even their closest friends and family. They feel they are only going through the motions of daily life
column13: and following a set of societal rules.   But
column14: the thing is
column15: their lives aren't any worse than anyone else's; in fact
column16: they live pretty good lives. Anyone in any situation anywhere on the planet could be feeling what the characters are. One gets the sense that the author feels this is the general human condition. What this means for us as a race of people is never explored; instead it's dealt with in sloppy
column17: broad strokes
column18: with an ending too dramatic and serious for the scope of the novel. The aspects of the novel that are meant to be ironic and funny are not creative enough to even be clever. Nor are the things that are meant to be shocking at all original enough to have us surprised. Skip this novel and rent American Beauty.

column1: The Summary (short version)  The characters...  Go to restaurants and drink.  Go to bars and drink.  Go home and drink.  Go to bullfights and drink.  Insult each other and drink.  P!ss and drink.  Go to sleep
column2: wake up and drink.  Take baths and drink.  Have sex and drink.  I became an alcoholic just by reading The Sun Also Rises.  Summary (the long version) Several expatriates lick their emotional wounds and cavort around spending money left by their rich parents. The protagonist
column3: Jake Barnes
column4: is a reporter left impotent by a war wound. He and Uncle Toby from Tristram Shandy could have had a ball together (if you've read Tristram Shandy by Laurence Sterne
column5: you'll get the joke). He's in love with the beautiful Brett Ashley
column6: but his impotence makes it impossible for their relationship to have much substance. She falls in and out of love with other men while he stands around watching and feeling jealous. A little bullfighting and violence and drinking later
column7: they're right back where they started: in limbo.  I've never cared for Ernest Hemingway's writing style. It's like he made sure you knew you were reading a story from a REAL man: very macho in tone and style.  And this coupled with the boringness of the story makes The Sun Also Rises a dreadful read

column1: As someone who lived (and
column2: I guess
column3: is still living) the life of a "gifted" person
column4: I'm not terribly surprised by what I found in this book.  Many of the problems held by gifted students originate not from parents but from bureaucrats--people who want to figure out how best to control their talents for profit.  There isn't much profit for the parents themselves
column5: so where's the profit going to come from?  Other than those kids marked by stock brokers and scientists for high-paying jobs
column6: what's left?  Political profit
column7: of course
column8: and this is Quart's real goal.  Quart simply oppresses her topic into non-existence unless it can produce the right kind of person that will be sure to vote the right way.  Scrabble players
column9: spelling bee kids
column10: math geniuses...they're all weird at best and dangerous at worst
column11: *especially* if they've been home-schooled or attend church.  Competitors in chess are hyper-competitive
column12: but (surprisingly?) kids participating in politically-charged poetry slams are "encouraging" and "supportive".  She weeps for school districts that support the gifted and thereby thwart the  "equal results" that certain political groups seek
column13: yet cannot find anything but disdain for programs that support the results of all students  simply (and clearly) because of the political party that happened to begin it.  Her descriptions of her subjects are caricatured so badly that one cannot have any faith in the descriptions.  And
column14: as some have noted below
column15: she has played loose and fast with those she quotes in order to make the right sort of case.  If you have the ability to ignore or refute the author's opinions through basic critical-reading skills
column16: you can get a basic idea of the sorts of issues faced by the gifted.  If not
column17: look elsewhere

column1: I find the mostly 5 star reviews of Adam Bede rather puzzling. I am a great of lover nineteenth century English lit
column2: and have enjoyed the other three Eliot books I've read--Middlemarch
column3: Silas Marner
column4: and Mill on the floss
column5: the latter being far and away my favorite. However
column6: had I read Adam Bede first
column7: I may not have bothered to read other Eliot works.   Eliot's talent is indisputable. The other reviews do an excellent job of capturing what is great about her prose
column8: and many of those strengths are present in Adam Bede. What disappointed me most about this work were the characters. Each was far less complex than I have come to expect from Eliot
column9: and I found the saintliness of Seth
column10: Adam
column11: and Dinah boring
column12: almost irritating. It was hard to care about them. I also found
column13: despite the explanations Eliot provided
column14: that Adam's love for Hetty and Dinah's change of heart about marriage was implausible.  What sealed my opinion of this book was Adam's forgiveness of Arthur. After the devastation Arthur's actions caused
column15: it would have been superhuman to forgive him
column16: let alone regard him as a friend. When Arthur asserted that he suffered more than Adam
column17: I could hardly believe that Adam did not recognize yet another expression of Arthur's massive ego.  Despite the book's strengths
column18: this flaw
column19: together with one-dimensional personalities of the main characters
column20: relegates Adam Bede to an inferior status among Eliot's works.

column8: view of history and metaphysical trivia. Over the years

column11: to me

column15: down on his luck
column16: and protests the state of civilization and wants to jump off the city hall building at midnight on Christmas Eve. Anyhow
column17: with this lie
column18: the paper actually re-hires Barbara
column19: hires Gary Cooper to be "John Doe
column20: and eventually starts a John Doe"/"love thy neighbor" movement that sweeps the country. One theme of this movie is that good things can come from a lie.  TUF
column21: in my opinion

Read TUF

column6: I became so disappointed
column7: I stop reading.  However
column8: my curiosity - inspired by the author's previous work - got the better of me
column9: and I picked it back up and skimmed to the end (encountering nothing to cause me to read for enjoyment).  The book's genre is the spy version of "detective thriller" - the hero runs from place to place collecting information from various "colorful" sources

column11: but it often came across as excessive and preachy (obsessive?).  Novels can provide a simplified version of a situation to reveal underlying truths
column12: but this book provides only a simplistic version - readers of "See no evil" may feel insulted
column13: not just disappointed.  I expected that part of the book would center on bureaucratic politics and infighting within the CIA and intelligence community
column14: but what was here was disappointing
column15: poorly set up and very badly rendered.  The ambiguities and uncertainties I would have expected were slight and peripheral to the main thread of the book.  Dialogue is often poorly rendered - it took effort to track which character was saying what - but this was a symptom of the bigger problems.  If you have this problem in an extended exchange involving only two characters
column16: there is a problem with the characters themselves and with the plot point that the dialogue is attempting to advance.  But some of the exchanges were so trite
column17: I didn't bother to make the effort.  Characters are minimally rendered.  The plot is slight.  Transitions between scenes are often jarring.  Too many of the situations strain credibility.  The ending made me feel not just cheated
column18: but betrayed (appropriate behavior for a Case Officier
column19: but not for an author).  Read "See no evil".  Skip this book - It could have just as easily been produced by a writer whose only experience was reading other books in this genre

column1: They have made several changes - some good
column2: most bad -  since I bought my last Sony handicam in 8/2003.  First of all
column3: there is no carrying strap.  This is very inconvenient if you plan to use your hand for anything else except for holding your camera.  I managed to jury rig one but it is a royal pain. The docking station is just one more thing to have to carry and when you want to upload your mini cassettes to your computer
column4: you have to take the camera off the docking station to change cassettes. This messes up my editing program.  Fortunately I still have my old camera.  The ability to take still shots is better - more megapixels - but not good enough to zoom in or enlarge.   While I was told most people prefer to use the LED screen (I don't knoiw why as it eats up more power and you can't see clearly in bright sun) I like to use the viewfinder.  It no longer has a tilt up feature so I end up mashing the battery into my cheek.  This last complaint is about the batteries. Sony LIED about the amount of time that a battery will hold.  The 5 hour battery only charges to 194 minutes on my camera. That's slightly more than 3 hours; It is nowhere near 5 hours.  The 7 hour battery does not get anywhere near 7 hours either. Their packages should be accurate.   All in all
column5: It is not as good as the older product.  There also should be a setting to stop it from running if the rec. button is not being pushed.   THIS WILL BE MY LAST SONY UNLESS THEY MAKE MAJOR IMPROVEMENTS

column1: I agree with the reviewer who felt that Ms. Shires's textual analysis didn't flow well.  I found the majority of this book to be rather dull
column2: tedious
column3: slow-going
column4: and uninvolving.  It was an original idea to tell the story of her conversion by relating issues she had difficulty with or areas she found inspiration in to certain passages of Torah and the similar writings of others
column5: but it just didn't seem executed well.  If this is supposed to be a conversion memoir
column6: why does so little of the book actually concern her conversion or even her herself?  The sections when Ms. Shires is writing about herself
column7: such as in the beginning section
column8: the ending chapter about her visit to her husband's native Germany
column9: and the middle chapter about the mikvah
column10: are quite good and interesting
column11: because they're actually related to her life and to her conversion and not just tediously rambling on about certain Torah passages.  From reading this
column12: it seems as though she were the classic child who does not know enough to ask.  She says she did a lot of reading prior to her conversion because she really wanted to know the religion and to approach it from a variety of disciplines
column13: but in many sections she admits that she didn't know about some pretty important things or issues till after she converted.  For example
column14: she says that she hadn't had a lot of education about the mikveh and had been too embarrassed to ask her converting rabbi
column15: and therefore went into her conversion day feeling she had to immerse herself because she was thought to be "contaminated" and "dirty" as a non-Jew and had to cleanse herself before being admitted to the tribe.  How could anyone in any denomination
column16: particularly if she's had such a long process of education and learning as Ms. Shires evidentally had
column17: reach conversion day thinking such a thing and not having learnt more about the custom of mikveh?  (I was also annoyed that her chapter on the mikveh used the dated and inaccurate translations "contaminated" and "unclean" for the Hebrew words "tumah" and "tamei."  That continues to give the completely false impression that menstruating women are thought to be dirty and unclean
column18: when in actual fact the words surrounding this state of being are translated more like "ritually impure
column19:
and the impurity refers to a spiritual, not a physical, state of being.)    I was also left wondering why she converted under the auspices of the Conservative Movement when she so clearly feels ill at ease with many of their official positions, or at least the positions her own community seems to take.  She really seems like she'd feel more at home in a Reform, Reconstructionist, or Renewal community.  I'm also baffled as to why she frequently says that the Conservative Movement hasn't done enough for the inclusion of gays and women, unless her community isn't as liberal as many other Conservative communities are.  Or are the changes of the past few decades not radical and sweeping enough for her?  I also share her belief that women, gays, the disabled, and other groups that traditionally haven't always been included fully in Jewish life need to be completely integrated and granted full equality and participation in the community, but at times her call for this reads more like a political polemic and speaking from personal experience as opposed to really representing the great strides the Conservative Movement has made in these areas in the past few decades.  I'm not doubting her personal experiences with people she's known and what she's dealt with in her own community, but it just seems baffling if she's trying to say the entire Conservative Movement takes those positions as well.  A couple of interesting chapters do not a very recommendable book make.  Most of this was just very slow going for me, and the divrei Torah weren't that novel or insightful either.  I've heard most of these interpretations and analyses before, only not in such dull language.  I'm actually disappointed I bought this book, though at least I got a cheap used copy.  I'd looked forward to reading a conversion memoir, but instead got a tedious exercise in boredom that had almost nothing to do with the author's life, either before, during, or after her conversion 
 If there is a passage that defines this book, it's the one on page 74, where he uses his superior intellect and social conservatism to declare that ...[the human assembler of pre-manufactured parts] is not necessarily a bad man. It merely means that his education in his trade has been bad."   What an amazing nugget of wisdom from a man who browbeats the greater population for our consumption of mass-manufactured objects. No
column20: David
column21: assemblers who aren't emotionally or pridefully connected to the object are just deficient people
column22: worthy of the utmost contempt. Start up a death camp if they bother that bad
column23: Nazi bastard. Labor thanks you for your morsels of understanding and forgiveness.  Don't waste your money. Don't make ugly work

column1: Conscious Acts of Creation: The Emergence of a new Physics by William A. Tiller
column2: Walter E. Dibble
column3: and Michael J. Kohane.  Publisher: Quality Books Inc. pages - 418  I like and don't like this book. It's billed as a book written for physics
column4: but also applicable to people into metaphysics. But the problem is that the writing for this book is not intended for a general audience. It's intended for an audience that has a developed awareness of the highly technical language of physics and math. As such many people into metaphysics will have a hard time reading this book. I did. I had to read and reread many sections to try and understand the language being used.  A big part of the problem is that the organtization of this book's chapters is highly erratic. The authors jump around a lot. I actually understood a few of the final chapters
column5: but only because the language was more general. I think it would have served the authors better to have put those chapters in the beginning of the text. Also none of the terms and acronyms were well defined or spelled out. A glossary would've done wonders for this book.  In defense of the book the ideas being worked with are intriguing and the authors did perk my interest and keep me reading...the problem is that while this book could interest a large audience of people
column6: it can only have a big impact on a much smaller audience because of the highly technical language
column7: bizarre layout
column8: and lack of cohesion. As such the potential good this book could do is marred by the inability of the authors to write in a more accessible manner.  I did manage to understand a fair amount of this book
column9: but I can only chalk that up to reading up a lot on physics and science. I only hope that the authors' other books are more accessible.  Regrettably I have to give this book two stars out of five and recommend to the authors that they work with an editor who can help them with layout issues and with language (in terms of making the language more accessible to a wider audience)

column1: I bought this book a number of years ago for apologetics purposes-- While I would agree with other reviewers that it holds a high view of Scripture
column2: and the book definitely represents a lot of research
column3: I think that the approach to symbology used here can be problematic.  The entire book is a study of constellations
column4: and how they display the Gospel in the Stars. While this is an interesting study I think there a oouple of underlying problems with this approach.   1.  Constellations and star names are simply assignments that man has assigned to stars.  Usually pagan cultures in association with their pagan mythology.  Although this does not completely undermine such a study it does call it into question. 2.  A second more serious problem is the same problem which underlies numerology and other allegorical approaches-- they can often be made to say anything the author even while at the same time appearing scholarly.    Those looking for apologetics in the cosmos should consider investigating the "anthropic principle" which tracks evidence of God's design of the universe.  One such book would be "Show me God" by Fred Hereen.  In terms of our faith
column5: In my opinion
column6: God's Word itself furnishes a lifetime of study without engaging in speculation of symbols which we really can't prove one way or the other.

column1: I expected this book to be a satire comparing the ridiculous actions of some wealthy people to similar behaviors found in the animal kingdom. When the book sticks to its satirical purpose it somewhat succeeds
column2: though I didn't find Conniff as funny as all the blurbs describing his "wittiness' would suggest.  But where I had a problem with this book is its one-sided perspective on human behavior
column3: which Conniff attempts to explain through the very narrow lens of "biology as destiny." Now don't get me wrong
column4: I definitely believe in Darwin's theory of evolution and the other basic ideas of science that have been proven through the "scientific method" of serious research and collected evidence. But
column5: as most people would agree
column6: BOTH nature and nuture play a part in human development. In other words both culture and biology are important factors in why humans behave as we do. This
column7: to me
column8: is common sense. But Conniff comes across as overly ideological in his biologically deterministic perspective. This is especially the case when he takes his jabs at feminists and others with a more "culturally based" point of view. I think there is much to be learned about humanity from studying the sciences. But I also believe in drawing from other ideas and academic disciplines in order to form a balanced basis of knowledge. Conniff fails to do that and for that reason I find his book does not ring true.

column1: By focusing on the separateness of the two individuals in unifying marriage

column1: "BRUTAL PLANET"  REVIEW:   In Alice Cooper's long and successful career (admittedly with ups and downs along the way)
column2: he has proved (to me at least) that he is one of the best lyricist in rock and roll history. Albums like "Love It To Death
column3: Killer
column4: Billion Dollar Babies
column5: and Welcome To My Nightmare" are just simply put - BRILLIANT. Alice was at the top of his game in the 70's. However
column6: that is not to suggest that he's never released worthy material since then. In fact the quite opposite. Albums like his 1983 hidden gem "Dada
column7: 1991's Hey Stoopid" and the brilliant "The Last Temptation" (1994) is amongst some of Alice's best work.  However
column8: in the summer of 2000
column9: Alice unleashed BRUTAL PLANET
column10: which was produced by Bob Marlette (Union - "The Blue Room") and executive produced by the great Bob Ezrin. While there are standout tracks like the title track
column11: "Sanctuary
column12: and Take It Like A Woman" --- the album just falls flat. The new musical direction (Nu-Metal) seems too forced which is truly unfortunate because the album boasts some of the best lyrics Alice has ever written.   MUSICIANS:  Ryan Roxie ... Guitars Phil X ... Guitars China ... Guitars Bob Marlette ... Bass Eric Singer ... Drums  INTERESTING FACTS:  1. Released by Spitfire Records
column13: "Brutal" Planet" peaked at #193 on the Billboard Top 200.  2. There was a Japanese/Australian bonus track called "Can't Sleep
column14: Clowns Will Eat Me". That title was actually inspired by dialogue spoken in the hit animated show "The Simpsons".  3. The stage show - which can be seen on the "Brutally Live" DVD - is a post-apocalyptic landscape of wreckage that also features the Frankenstein machine
column15: a Guillotine
column16: two TV`s - and in some cases - three TV's showing weird video footage all through out the show.   PACKAGING:  The album cover - which was created by Kane Roberts' company PlanetFX - is a decent and once again
column17: the booklet does feature  the album's lyrics.  APPROX. RUNNING TIME:  48 min. and 4 sec.  FINAL ANALYSIS:  Musically the album just plods along and is devoid of any real energy. Despite being lyrically well-written
column18: "Brutal Planet" is certainly the most disappointing release from Alice since his 1989 album
column19: "Trash". **1/2 out of 5.

column1: I agree with a previous review that you get what you pay for.  But in the future I would highly recommend paying more once instead of having to replace this food in a few months or so. But we have had this package of food for about one week and I am already taping boxes with packaging tape to keep them together.  Little hands can pull apart the milk

column3: pizza
column4: and such food are all actually hollow underneath.  There is no base to them.  They tell you 101 pieces but in our kit it counted 8 hotdogs (without buns)
column5: 12 individual french fries and the same on potato chips.  Not necessary especially since you also get two french fry packets in a french fry container and you get a hot dog in a bun separately.  Why would my child want four jalepenos too.  So much of this food is not they type of thing a small child would be familiar with.  Anyway
column6: in my opinion spend the money on a smaller quantity of higher quality food or go online and find the "vintage" Fisher Price or Little Tikes food.  Now those are made to last and of good size for small hands.

column14: this album is better
column15: but compared to Outkast's other work
column16: it is a huge letdown. Southernplayalisticadillacmusik was a tempting showcase of talent that foreshadowed the good things to come
column17: but it was pretty standard fare for southern rap at the time
column18: although done better than most with a few hints of experimentation. (3 1/2 stars). Outakast really broke through with ATLiens with stripped down beats and ambient highs and thoughtful lyrics (5 stars). Aquemini (5 stars since that's the highest mark

It was (and still is) an absolutely amazing album that can be held up as a standard against which others can be measured. (Only Goodie Mob's "Soul Food" is on a similar level in my opinion.) Stankonia was a bit of a drop off after Aquemini
column20: but still an extremely solid effort with some standout tracks like "Gasoline Dreams" and "Humble Mumble." (4 Stars). But
column21: with this latest release
column22: Outkast seems to have lost some of the edge that made their earlier albums so great. I respect Outkast for constantly trying new things (that is what made ATLiens and Aquemini instant classics) and can understand that sometimes expiramentation will not go as planned. Given that

column1: This Workbood back-fired.  The theory appears sound
column2: but when it came to my wife and me working through the Workbook together
column3: we found a serious trap (surely unintended) by diligently following the instructions
column4: exactly.  Session 7 is entitled "Re-Romanticizing your Relationship I:  Caring Behaviors."  It directs each person to list the behaviors he/she has "always wanted but have never asked for."  The instructions then elaborate by saying the wants may be "your vision of a perfect mate...may be private fantasies or secret desires."  They fail to limit the scope.  There are some behaviors over which a person may have no control such as medication side-effects or physiological depression.  Following the instructions blindly and trusting they allow for and deal with such situations. I honestly included some desires that my mate is unable to provide. These lists were then exchanged. She appeared to accept them at the time
column5: but they actually caused her a great deal of anguish.  So my wife now knows my fantasy wants but she cannot fulfill them even though she would very much like to.  This left her feeling inadequate to the point she gave me an "out" of our relationship of many years.  That is the last thing I would ever want.  As a result
column6: I am quite angry and feeling very guilty.  Looking ahead to the next sessions
column7: not only do they not deal with this type of possibility
column8: but they use these lists to intensify the exercises.  I should have known better.  We threw the books in the trash.  We have  spent a good deal of time overcoming those feelings of hurt and regret.  From the beginning
column9: I have had trouble with the title as
column10: to me
column11: "wants" has its roots in selfishness

column1: After reading the table of contents
column2: I purchased this book
column3: expecting it to be a dispassionate history of famous economists.  By the middle of the text however
column4: I came to realize that the author was embedding within his extensive knowledge of economic history his unabashed distaste of free market capitalism.    The premise of the book
column5: (and of the title)
column6: is that the great fallacy of Adam Smith (and most other economists) is that they offer nothing to deal with the supposed immoral gap between the rich and poor.  While R. Stone (above) addresses this point by pointing to the fact that Smith does in fact discuss this issue at length in The Theory of Moral Sentiments
column7: I prefer to address it from a different direction.  Foley's argument
column8: focusing on the wide gap existing in capitalist societies between the rich and poor completely overlooks the absolute gains made by all under free market societies
column9: versus their socialist counterparts.  Paraphrasing the great Thomas Sowell
column10: economics is not a system of morals
column11: but rather a means by which scarce resource which have alternate uses are rationed most efficiently.  Chapter three most clearly shows the author's bias
column12: in his glowing description of socialism
column13: which in the end only euphemistically discusses the political difficulties in administering such a society.  Page 204 is perhaps the best example of this bias:    "Furthermore
column14: the Soviet Union did indeed manage to organize an impressive spurt of economic development
column15: extension of the division of labor
column16: and growth of productive capacity through its central planning mechanisms for what turned out to be a period of sixty years".  Nowhere in the text did Foley describe the now infamous rotting food in villages neighboring areas of starvation in the USSR.  He does not mention the dominant theory among respected economists that the surplus value created by a capitalist society
column17: and unevenly distributed to a certain class is what creates the incentives for goods (like food) to be distributed to the populace.  Above all else
column18: he does not ever mention the abject human rights violations ubiquitous in socialist regimes such as China under Mao
column19: Cuba
column20: USSR
column21: etc.  Granted
column22: these abuses of power are not part of the system of socialism
column23: but it is interesting nonetheless that they so often occur in societies which embrace their tenants.  Chapter five's description of Keynes was most interesting
column24: in my opinion
column25: for the strong weight Foley gave to his assertion that Say's Law is wrong
column26: thereby destroying the theories of free trade
column27: and opening the door to protectionist tariffs.  What was notably missing from this discussion
column28: however
column29: were stats on the falling unemployment rates for *both* the US and Mexico in the years after Clinton signed NAFTA
column30: or the continuously dropping unemployment rates
column31: and job creation in recent years
column32: during extensive outsourcing.  Nor does Foley treat the Great Depression with any objectivity.  After describing the horrible conditions the US and world were facing in the thirties
column33: and shortly thereafter
column34: he states "To contemporary observers
column35: laissez-faire policy seemed to be inadequate to cope with the problems of advanced industrial capitalism".  What Foley fails to mention here is that FDR had a horribly anti-free market policy during the depression
column36: which many economists now believe exacerbated matters
column37: ie
column38: setting price floors
column39: which helped small farms at the expense of consumers who could no longer afford to buy food.   To his credit
column40: however
column41: Foley does end his book with a good joke:  "On the whole
column42: historically the best results seem to come from modest
column43: and limited efforts to build institutions such as central banks
column44: social security ...".  It seems as though the best compliment Foley can come up with for capitalist societies is Social Security
column45: a system which
column46: under current operation
column47: is scheduled to be completely bankrupt in thirty or forty years.

column1: Very rarely does a film improve upon the source novel. I wrote a review of one
column2: King's Ransom
column3: which was made into a vastly superior film by Akira Kurosawa called High and Low. Goldfinger
column4: the film
column5: is one of the classic Bonds -- my favorite
column6: to be sure. The novel
column7: in contrast
column8: is too long
column9: is illogical in some parts
column10: offensive in others and makes the reader realize what a superb job screenwriter Richard Maibaum did in adapting it for the film. These weaknesses stand out in particular:  First
column11: the behavior of villain Auric Goldfinger is completely illogical during the torture scene. You might remember the terrific laser beam scene in the film where Goldfinger
column12: played by Gert Frobe
column13: threatens to slice James Bond
column14: played by the great Sean Connery
column15: in half. In the film
column16: Bond gets out of the mess by bluffing
column17: making Goldfinger believe that he knows all about Operation Grand Slam
column18: Goldfinger's plan to blow up Fort Knox. Goldfinger reasons that he can keep the CIA and the British Secret Service at bay by keeping Bond alive and making them think that Bond is his guest
column19: not his prisoner.  The novel
column20: in contrast
column21: has Goldfinger threaten Bond with a saw. Bond doesn't mention Operation Grand Slam and has been a constant thorn in Goldfinger's side. Goldfinger has Bond dead to rights and
column22: unlike in the laser beam scene in the film
column23: has no logical reason to spare his life. However
column24: just before Bond is about to be sawed in half
column25: Goldfinger inexplicably spares him and forces Bond to pose as his secretary. There's a running joke that Bond villains seal their own fate by devising elaborate ways to kill him that allow Bond to escape. However
column26: Goldfinger's action in this scene in the novel completely defy logic and cripple the story's credibility. Bond novels are an escape from reality -- an adult comic book -- but this plot development makes absolutely no sense.  In the novel
column27: Goldfinger's plan is to rob Fort Knox of its gold supply. Fleming
column28: unlike Richard Maibaum
column29: apparently never realized how logistically impossible this is. Connery rightfully points out in the film that to rob Fort Knox would require a whole fleet of trucks and several days to complete. Maibaum's plan
column30: while still fantastic
column31: makes more sense -- detonating a nuclear weapon in Fort Knox to irradiate the U.S. gold supply and drive the value of his own supply up ten times over.  In the novel
column32: Pussy Galore begins as a hardened lesbian who has no interest in Bond whatsoever. Of course
column33: by the end of the novel
column34: Bond has "heterosexualized" and overwhelmed her with his masculine charms. It's a very 1950's view of homosexualtiy -- that is
column35: that a homosexual could be "cured" of his/her sexual desires like it was a disease. The attitude seems very backward and ignorant by today's standards.  The film strongly suggests Pussy's lesbianism
column36: but it also shows Pussy
column37: played by Honor Blackman
column38: flirting suggestively with Bond. Blackman's Pussy may have lesbian tendencies
column39: but she clearly also has a strong attraction to the opposite sex. When she falls for Bond
column40: it makes sense
column41: unlike in the novel. Bond still converts her
column42: but the conversion stressed is more along the lines of Pussy joining the good guys rather than going from staunch lesbianism to being a Bond girl.  The film has a lot of Asian villains. Harold Sakata is terrific as Goldfinger's superpowered Korean henchman Oddjob
column43: Burt Kwouk (Kato in the Pink Panther films) is Mr. Ling
column44: a Chinese nuclear scientist who supplies Goldfinger with the bomb and most of Goldfinger's henchmen are Korean. However
column45: the film

column1: Hugh's book is a disappointment.  It seems like a rush job thrown together to peddle during the election.  Not much scholarship was done either.  For example
column2: he asserts that when Gore tried to block overseas military ballots from being counted
column3: not a single democrat raised their voice in opposition; he must not have done a lexis/nexis search because Gore supporter Zell Miller was very vocal in opposing the effort to block military votes.  Further
column4: very little was done to cite specific situations of democrat party vote (...).  The way Hugh segments the parties into pyramids and his description of the interplay between segments was useful -- but did not merit a hardcover book purchase.  Various Bush speeches re: 9/11 have been attached at the back for reference (perhaps to boost the page count?).  I like Hugh and I love his radio show
column5: but Hugh has a fairly cerebral audience
column6: and this book was more appropriate for Sean Hannity groupies

column1: Fact of the matter is
column2: even Lovecraft didn't pull off a good story every time
column3: so it's even harder for people who write their own Mythos stories to do a good job. All too often
column4: Mythos imitators misuse the conventions of the genre
column5: with the mysterious elements brought right into the open so the writer's hero can solve them with some half-baked solution. This is in contrast to HP Lovecraft's stories
column6: which mostly ended with the protagonist getting eaten by something or shooting himself. This anthology does not add much to what could have been the richest horror genre of them all. Instead
column7: it just piles on more so-so stories that aren't innovative or all that memorable. It's not that the stories are universally bad
column8: they're just so much less than they could have been
column9: given the material the authors had to work with
